verses.text: Language is vain to set forth, not only the generation of the Son, but even the works of God, for it is written: "All His works are executed in faithfulness;" His works, then, are done in faithfulness, but not His generation? Ay, we call in question that which we see not, we who are bidden to believe rather than enquire of that we see.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:1
verses.text: Chapter XIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:2
verses.text: Discussion of the Divine Generation is continued.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:3
verses.text: St.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:4
verses.text: Ambrose illustrates its method by the same example as that employed by the author of the Epistle to the Hebrews.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:5
verses.text: The duty of believing what is revealed is shown by the example of Nebuchadnezzar and St.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:6
verses.text: Peter.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:7
verses.text: By the vision granted to St.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:8
verses.text: Peter was shown the Son's Eternity and Godhead—the Apostle, then, must be believed in preference to the teachers of philosophy, whose authority was everywhere falling into discredit.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:9
verses.text: The Arians, on the other hand, are shown to be like unto the heathen.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:10
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:11
verses.text: It will be asked: "In what sort was the Son begotten?" As one who is for ever, as the Word, as the brightness of eternal light, for brightness takes effect in the instant of its coming into existence.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:12
verses.text: Which example is the Apostle's, not mine.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:13
verses.text: Think not, then, that there was ever a moment of time when God was without wisdom, any more than that there was ever a time when light was without radiance.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:14
verses.text: Judge not, Arian, divine things by human, but believe the divine where thou findest not the human.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:15
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:16
verses.text: The heathen king saw in the fire, together with the three Hebrew children, the form of a fourth, like as of an angel, and because he thought that this angel excelled all angels, he judged Him to be the Son of God, Whom he had not read of, but in Whom  he believed.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:17
verses.text: Abraham, also, saw Three, and adored One.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:18
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:19
verses.text: Peter, when he saw Moses and Elias on the mountain, with the Son of God, was not deceived as to their nature and glory.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:20
verses.text: For he enquired, not of them, but of Christ, what he ought to do, inasmuch as though he prepared to do homage to all three, yet he waited for the command of one.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:21
verses.text: But since he ignorantly thought that for three persons three tabernacles should be set up, he was corrected by the sovereign voice of God the Father, saying, "This is My dearly beloved Son: hear ye Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:22
verses.text: That is to say: "Why dost thou join thy fellow-servants in equality with thy Lord?" "This is My Son".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:23
verses.text: Not "Moses is My Son," nor "Elias is My Son," but "This is My Son".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:24
verses.text: The Apostle was not dull to understand the rebuke; he fell on his face, brought low by the Father's voice and the glorious beauty of the Son, but he was raised up by the Son, Whose wont it is to raise up them that are fallen.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:25
verses.text: Then he saw one only, the Son of God alone, for the servants had withdrawn, that He might be seen to be Lord alone, Who alone was entitled Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:26
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:27
verses.text: What, then, was the purpose of that vision, which signified not that Christ and His servants were equal, but betokened a mystery, save that it should be made plain to us that the Law and the Prophets, in agreement with the Gospel, revealed as eternal the Son of God, Whom they had heralded.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:28
verses.text: When we, therefore, hear of the Son coming forth of the womb, the Word from the heart, let us believe that the Son was not fashioned with hands but begotten of the Father, not the work of a craftsman but the offspring of a parent.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:29
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:30
verses.text: He, therefore, Who said, "This is My Son," said not, "This is a creature of time," nor "This being is of My creation, My making, My servant," but "This is My Son, Whom ye see glorified".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:31
verses.text: This is the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, the God of Jacob, Who appeared to Moses in the bush, concerning Whom Moses saith, "He Who is hath sent me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:32
verses.text: It was not the Father Who spake to Moses in the bush or in the desert, but the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:33
verses.text: It was of this Moses that Stephen said, "This is He Who was in the church, in the wilderness, with the Angel".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:34
verses.text: This, then, is He Who gave the Law, Who spake with Moses, saying, "I am the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, the God of Jacob".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:35
verses.text: This, then, is the God of the patriarchs, this is the God of the prophets.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:36
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:37
verses.text: It is of the Son, therefore, that we read, thy mind understandeth the reading, let thy tongue make confession.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:38
verses.text: Away with arguments, where faith is required; now let dialectic hold her peace, even in the midst of her schools.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:39
verses.text: I ask not what it is that philosophers say, but I would know what they do.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:40
verses.text: They sit desolate in their schools.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:41
verses.text: See the victory of faith over argument.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:42
verses.text: They who dispute subtly are forsaken daily by their fellows; they who with simplicity believe are daily increased.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:43
verses.text: Not philosophers but fishermen, not masters of dialectic but tax-gatherers, now find credence.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:44
verses.text: The one sort, through pleasures and luxuries, have bound the world's burden upon themselves; the other, by fasting and mortification, have cast it off, and so doth sorrow now begin to win over more followers than pleasure.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:45
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:46
verses.text: Let us now see how far Arians and pagans do differ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:47
verses.text: The latter call upon gods, who are different in sex and unequal in power; the former affirm a Trinity where there is likewise inequality of power and diversity of Godhead.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:48
verses.text: The pagans assert that their Gods began to exist once upon a time; the Arians lyingly declare that Christ began to exist in the course of time.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 13:49
verses.text: Have they not all dyed their impiety in the vats of philosophy? But indeed the pagans do extol that which they worship, the Arians maintain that the Son of God, Who is God, is a creature.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:1
verses.text: Chapter XIV.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:2
verses.text: That the Son of God is not a created being is proved by the following arguments: (1) That He commanded not that the Gospel should be preached to Himself; (2) that a created being is given over unto vanity; (3) that the Son has created all things; (4) that we read of Him as begotten; and (5) that the difference of generation and adoption has always been understood in those places where both natures—the divine and the human—are declared to co-exist in Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:3
verses.text: All of which testimony is confirmed by the Apostle's interpretation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:4
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:5
verses.text: It is now made plain, as I believe, your sacred Majesty, that the Lord Jesus is neither unlike the Father, nor one that began to exist in course of time.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:6
verses.text: We have yet to confute another blasphemy, and to show that the Son of God is not a created being.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:7
verses.text: Herein is the quickening word that we read as our help, for we have heard the  passage read where the Lord saith: "Go ye into all the world, and preach the Gospel to all creation".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:8
verses.text: He Who saith "all creation" excepts nothing.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:9
verses.text: How, then, do they stand who call Christ a "creature"? If He were a creature, could He have commanded that the Gospel should be preached to Himself? It is not, therefore, a creature, but the Creator, Who commits to His disciples the work of teaching created beings.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:10
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:11
verses.text: Christ, then, is no created being; for "created beings are," as the Apostle hath said, "given over to vanity".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:12
verses.text: Is Christ given over unto vanity? Again, "creation"—according to the same Apostle—"groans and travails together even until now".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:13
verses.text: What, then? Doth Christ take any part in this groaning and travailing—He Who hath set us miserable mourners free from death? "Creation," saith the Apostle, "shall be set free from the slavery of corruption".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:14
verses.text: We see, then, that between creation and its Lord there is a vast difference, for creation is enslaved, but "the Lord is the Spirit, and where the Spirit of the Lord is, there is freedom".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:15
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:16
verses.text: Who was it that led first into this error, of declaring Him Who created and made all things to be a creature? Did the Lord, I would ask, create Himself? We read that "all things were made by Him, and without Him was nothing made".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:17
verses.text: This being so, did He make Himself? We read—and who shall deny?—that in wisdom hath God made all things.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:18
verses.text: If so, how can we suppose that wisdom was made in itself?  89.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:19
verses.text: We read that the Son is begotten, inasmuch as the Father saith: "I brought thee forth from the womb before the morning star".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:20
verses.text: We read of the "first-born" Son, of the "only-begotten"—first-born, because there is none before Him; only-begotten, because there is none after Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:21
verses.text: Again, we read: "Who shall declare His generation?" "Generation," mark you, not "creation".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:22
verses.text: What argument can be brought to meet testimonies so great and mighty as these?  90.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:23
verses.text: Moreover, God's Son discovers the difference between generation and grace when He says: "I go up to My Father and your Father, to My God and your God".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:24
verses.text: He did not say, "I go up to our Father," but "I go up to My Father and your Father".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:25
verses.text: This distinction is the sign of a difference, inasmuch as He Who is Christ's Father is our Creator.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:26
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:27
verses.text: Furthermore He said, "to My God and your God," because although He and the Father are One, and the Father is His Father by possession of the same nature, whilst God began to be our Father through the office of the Son, not by virtue of nature, but of grace—still He seems to point us here to the existence in Christ of both natures, Godhead and Manhood,—Godhead of His Father, Manhood of His Mother, the former being before all things, the latter derived from the Virgin.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:28
verses.text: For the first, speaking as the Son, He called God His Father, and afterward, speaking as man, named Him as God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:29
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:30
verses.text: Everywhere, indeed, we have witness in the Scriptures to show that Christ, in naming God as His God, does so as man.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:31
verses.text: "My God, My God, why hast Thou forsaken Me?" And again: "From My mother's womb Thou art My God".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:32
verses.text: In the former place He suffers as a man; in the latter it is a man who is brought forth from his mother's womb.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:33
verses.text: And so when He says, "From My mother's womb Thou art My God," He means that He Who was always His Father is His God from the moment when He was brought forth from His Mother's womb.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:34
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:35
verses.text: Seeing, then, that we read in the Gospel, in the Apostle, in the Prophets, of Christ as begotten, how dare the Arians to say that He was created or made? But, indeed, they ought to have bethought them, where they have read of Him as created, where as made.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:36
verses.text: For it has been plainly shown that the Son of God is begotten of God, born of God—let them, then, consider with care where they have read that He was made, seeing that He was not made God, but born as God, the Son of God; afterward, however, He was, according to the flesh, made man of Mary.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:37
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:38
verses.text: "But when the fulness of time was come, God sent His Son, made of a woman, made under the Law".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:39
verses.text: "His Son," observe, not as one of many, not as His in common with another, but His own, and in saying "His Son," the Apostle showed that it is of the Son's nature that His generation is eternal.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:40
verses.text: Him the Apostle has affirmed to have been afterwards "made" of a woman, in order that the making might be understood not of the Godhead, but of the putting  on of a body—"made of a woman," then, by taking on of flesh; "made under the Law" through observance of the Law.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 14:41
verses.text: Howbeit, the former, the spiritual generation is before the Law was, the latter is after the Law.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:1
verses.text: Chapter XV.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:2
verses.text: An explanation of Acts ii.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:3
verses.text: 36 and Proverbs viii.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:4
verses.text: 22 , which are shown to refer properly to Christ's manhood alone.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:5
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:6
verses.text: To no purpose, then, is the heretics' customary citation of the Scripture, that "God made Him both Lord and Christ".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:7
verses.text: Let these ignorant persons read the whole passage, and understand it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:8
verses.text: For thus it is written.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:9
verses.text: "God made this Jesus, Whom ye crucified, both Lord and Christ".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:10
verses.text: It was not the Godhead, but the flesh, that was crucified.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:11
verses.text: This, indeed, was possible, because the flesh allowed of being crucified.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:12
verses.text: It follows not, then, that the Son of God is a created being.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:13
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:14
verses.text: Let us despatch, then, that passage also, which they do use to misrepresent,—let them learn what is the sense of the words, "The Lord created Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:15
verses.text: It is not "the Father created," but "the Lord created Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:16
verses.text: The flesh acknowledgeth its Lord, praise declareth the Father: our created nature confesseth the first, loveth, knoweth the latter.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:17
verses.text: Who, then, cannot but perceive that these words announce the Incarnation? Thus the Son speaketh of Himself as created in respect of that wherein he witnesseth to Himself as being man, when He says, "Why seek ye to kill Me, a man, Who have told you the truth?" He speaketh of His Manhood, wherein He was crucified, and died, and was buried.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:18
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:19
verses.text: Furthermore, there is no doubt but that the writer set down as past that which was to come; for this is the usage of prophecy, that things to come are spoken of as though they were already present or past.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:20
verses.text: For example, in the twenty-first psalm you have read: "Fat bulls (of Bashan) have beset me," and again: "They parted My garments among them".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:21
verses.text: This the Evangelist showeth to have been spoken prophetically of the time of the Passion, for to God the things that are to come are present, and for Him Who foreknoweth all things, they are as though they were past and over; as it is written, "Who hath made the things that are to be".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:22
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:23
verses.text: It is no wonder that He should declare His place to have been set fast before all worlds, seeing that the Scripture tells us that He was foreordained before the times and ages.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:24
verses.text: The following passage discovers how the words in question present themselves as a true prophecy of the Incarnation: "Wisdom hath built her an house, and set up seven pillars to support it, and she hath slain her victims.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:25
verses.text: She hath mingled her wine in the bowl, and made ready her table, and sent her servants, calling men together with a mighty voice of proclamation, saying: 'He who is simple, let him turn in to me.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:26
verses.text: '" Do we not see, in the Gospel, that all these things were fulfilled after the Incarnation, in that Christ disclosed the mysteries of the Holy Supper, sent forth His apostles, and cried with a loud voice, saying, "If any man thirst, let him come to Me and drink".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:27
verses.text: That which followeth, then, answereth to that which went before, and we behold the whole story of the Incarnation set forth in brief by prophecy.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:28
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 15:29
verses.text: Many other passages might readily be seen to be prophecies of this sort concerning the Incarnation, but I will not delay over books, lest the treatise appear too wordy.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:1
verses.text: Chapter XVI.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:2
verses.text: The Arians blaspheme Christ, if by the words "created" and "begotten" they mean and understand one and the same thing.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:3
verses.text: If, however, they regard the words as distinct in meaning, they must not speak of Him, of Whom they have read that He was begotten, as if He were a created being.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:4
verses.text: This rule is upheld by the witness of St.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:5
verses.text: Paul, who, professing himself a servant of Christ, forbade worship of a created being.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:6
verses.text: God being a substance pure and uncompounded, there is no created nature in Him; furthermore, the Son is not to be degraded to the level of things created, seeing that in Him the Father is well pleased.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:7
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:8
verses.text: Now will I enquire particularly of the Arians, whether they think that begotten and created are one and the same.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:9
verses.text: If they call them the same, then is there no difference betwixt generation and creation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:10
verses.text: It follows, then, that forasmuch as we also are created, there is between us and Christ and the elements no difference.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:11
verses.text: Thus much, however, great as their madness is, they will not venture to say.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:12
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:13
verses.text: Furthermore—to concede that which is no truth, to their folly—I ask them, if there is, as they think, no difference in the words, why do they not call upon Him Whom they worship by the better title? Why do they not avail themselves of the Father's word? Why do they reject the title of honour, and use a dishonouring name?  102.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:14
verses.text: If, however, there is—as I think there is—a distinction between "created" and "begotten," then, when we have read that He is begotten, we shall surely not understand the same by the terms "begotten" and "created".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:15
verses.text: Let them therefore confess Him to be begotten of the Father, born of the Virgin, or let them say how the Son of God can be both begotten and created.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:16
verses.text: A single nature, above all, the Divine Being, rejects strife (within itself).

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:17
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:18
verses.text: But in any case let our private judgment pass: let us enquire of Paul, who, filled with the Spirit of God, and so foreseeing these questionings, hath given sentence against pagans in general and Arians in particular, saying that they were by God's judgment condemned, who served the creature rather than the Creator.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:19
verses.text: Thus, in fact, you may read: "God gave them over to the lusts of their own heart, that they might one with another dishonour their bodies, they who changed God's truth into a lie, and worshipped and served the thing created rather than the Creator, Who is God, blessed for ever".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:20
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:21
verses.text: Thus Paul forbids me to worship a creature, and admonishes me of my duty to serve Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:22
verses.text: It follows, then, that Christ is not a created being.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:23
verses.text: The Apostle calls himself "Paul, a servant of Jesus Christ," and this good servant, who acknowledges his Lord, will likewise have us not worship that which is created.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:24
verses.text: How, then, could he have been himself a servant of Christ, if he thought that Christ was a created person? Let these heretics, then, cease either to worship Him Whom they call a created being, or to call Him a creature, Whom they feign to worship, lest under colour of being worshippers they fall into worse impiety.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:25
verses.text: For a domestic is worse than a foreign foe, and that these men should use the Name of Christ to Christ's dishonour increaseth their guilt.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:26
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:27
verses.text: What better expounder of the Scriptures do we indeed look for than that teacher of the Gentiles, that chosen vessel—chosen from the number of the persecutors? He who had been the persecutor of Christ confesses Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:28
verses.text: He had read Solomon more, in any case, than Arius hath, and he was well learned in the Law, and so, because he had read, he said not that Christ was created, but that He was begotten.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:29
verses.text: For he had read, "He spake, and they were made: He commanded, and they were created".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:30
verses.text: Was Christ, I ask, made at a word? Was He created at a command?  106.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:31
verses.text: Moreover, how can there be any created nature in God? In truth, God is of an uncompounded nature; nothing can be added to Him, and that alone which is Divine hath He in His nature; filling all things, yet nowhere Himself confounded with aught; penetrating all things, yet Himself nowhere to be penetrated; present in all His fulness at one and the same moment, in heaven, in earth, in the deepest depth of the sea, to sight invisible, by speech not to be declared, by feeling not to be measured; to be followed by faith, to be adored with devotion; so that whatsoever title excels in depth of spiritual import, in setting forth glory and honour, in exalting power, this you may know to belong of right to God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:32
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:33
verses.text: Since, then, the Father is well pleased in the Son; believe that the Son is worthy of the Father, that He came out from God, as He Himself bears witness, saying: "I went out from God, and am come;" and again: "I went out from God".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 16:34
verses.text: He Who proceeded and came forth  from God can have no attributes but such as are proper to God.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:1
verses.text: Chapter XVII.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:2
verses.text: That Christ is very God is proved from the fact that He is God's own Son, also from His having been begotten and having come forth from God, and further, from the unity of will and operation subsisting in Father and Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:3
verses.text: The witness of the apostles and of the centurion—which St.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:4
verses.text: Ambrose sets over against the Arian teaching—is adduced, together with that of Isaiah and St.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:5
verses.text: John.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:6
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:7
verses.text: Hence it is that Christ is not only God, but very God indeed—very God of very God, insomuch that He Himself is the Truth.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:8
verses.text: If, then, we enquire His Name, it is "the Truth;" if we seek to know His natural rank and dignity, He is so truly the very Son of God, that He is indeed God's own Son; as it is written, "Who spared not His own Son, but gave Him up for our sakes," gave Him up, that is, so far as the flesh was concerned.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:9
verses.text: That He is God's own Son declares His Godhead; that He is very God shows that He is God's own Son; His pitifulness is the earnest of His submission, His sacrifice, of our salvation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:10
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:11
verses.text: Lest, however, men should wrest the Scripture, that "God gave Him up," the Apostle himself has said in another place, "Peace from God the Father, and our Lord Jesus Christ, Who gave Himself for our sins;" and again: "Even as Christ hath loved us, and given Himself for us".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:12
verses.text: If, then, He both was given up by the Father, and gave Himself up of His own accord, it is plain that the working and the will of Father and Son is one.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:13
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:14
verses.text: If, then, we enquire into His natural pre-eminence, we find it to consist in being begotten.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:15
verses.text: To deny that the Son of God is begotten [of God] is to deny that He is God's own Son, and to deny Christ to be God's own Son is to class Him with the rest of mankind, as no more a Son than any of the rest.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:16
verses.text: If, however, we enquire into the distinctive property of His generation, it is this, that He came forth from God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:17
verses.text: For whilst, in our experience, to come out implies something already existent, and that which is said to come out seems to proceed forth from hidden and inward places, we, though it be presented but in short passages, observe the peculiar attribute of the Divine Generation, that the Son doth not seem to have come forth out of any place, but as God from God, a Son from a Father, nor to have had a beginning in the course of time, having come forth from the Father by being born, as He Himself Who was born said: "I came forth from the mouth of the Most High".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:18
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:19
verses.text: But if the Arians acknowledge not the Son's nature, if they believe not the Scriptures, let them at least believe the mighty works.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:20
verses.text: To whom doth the Father say, "Let us make man?" save to Him Whom He knew to be His true Son? In Whom, save in one who was true, could He recognize His Image? The son by adoption is not the same as the true Son; nor would the Son say, "I and the Father are one," if He, being Himself not true, were measuring Himself with One Who is true.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:21
verses.text: The Father, therefore, says, "Let us make".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:22
verses.text: He Who spake is true; can He, then, Who made be not true? Shall the honour rendered to Him Who speaks be withheld from Him Who makes?  112.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:23
verses.text: But how, unless the Father knew Him to be His true Son, should He commend to Him His will, for perfect co-operation, and His works, for perfect bringing in out in actuality? Seeing that the Son worketh the works which the Father doeth, and that the Son quickens whom He will, as it is written, He is then equal in power and free in respect of His will.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:24
verses.text: And thus is the Unity maintained, forasmuch as God's power consists in that the Godhead is proper to each Person, and freedom lies not in any difference, but in unity of will.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:25
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:26
verses.text: The apostles, being storm-tossed in the sea, as soon as they saw the waters leaping up round their Lord's feet, and beheld His fearless footsteps on the water, as He walked amid the raging waves of the sea, and the ship, which was beaten upon by the waves, had rest as soon as Christ entered it, and they saw the waves and the winds obeying Him,—then, though as yet they did not believe in their hearts they believed Him to be God's true Son, saying, "Truly Thou art the Son of God".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:27
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:28
verses.text: To the same effect the confession of the centurion, and others who were with him, when the foundations of the world were shaken at the Lord's Passion,—and this, heretic, thou deniest! The centurion said, "Truly this was the Son of God".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:29
verses.text: "Was" said the centurion—"Was not" says the Arian.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:30
verses.text: The centurion, then, with bloodstained hands, but devout mind,  declares both the truth and the eternity of Christ's generation; and thou, O heretic, deniest its truth, and makest it matter of time! Would that thou hadst imbued thy hands rather than thy soul! But thou, unclean even of hand, and murderous of intent, seekest Christ's death, so far as in thee lies, seeing that thou thinkest of Him as mean and weak; nay, and this is a worse sin, thou, albeit the Godhead can feel no wound, still wouldst do thy diligence to slay in Christ, not His Body, but His Glory.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:31
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:32
verses.text: We cannot then doubt that He is very God, Whose true Godhead even executioners believed in and devils confessed.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:33
verses.text: Their testimony we require not now, but it is withal greater than your blasphemies.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:34
verses.text: We have called them in to witness, to put you to the blush, whilst we have also cited the oracles of God, to the end that you should believe.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:35
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:36
verses.text: The Lord proclaimeth by the mouth of Isaiah: "In the mouth of them that serve Me shall a new name be called upon, which shall be blessed over all the earth, and they shall bless the true God, and they who swear upon earth shall swear by the true God".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:37
verses.text: These words, I say, Isaiah spake when he saw God's Glory, and thus in the Gospel it is plainly said that he saw the Glory of Christ and spoke of Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:38
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:39
verses.text: But hear again what John the Evangelist hath written in his Epistle, saying: "We know that the Son of God hath appeared, and hath given us discernment, to know the Father, and to be in His true Son Jesus Christ, our Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:40
verses.text: He is very God, and Life Eternal".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:41
verses.text: John calls Him true Son of God and very God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 17:42
verses.text: If, then, He be very God, He is surely uncreate, without spot of lying or deceit, having in Himself no confusion, nor unlikeness to His Father.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 18

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 18:1
verses.text: Chapter XVIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 18:2
verses.text: The errors of the Arians are mentioned in the Nicene Definition of the Faith, to prevent their deceiving anybody.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 18:3
verses.text: These errors are recited, together with the anathema pronounced against them, which is said to have been not only pronounced at Nicaea, but also twice renewed at Ariminum.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 18:4
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 18:5
verses.text: Christ, therefore, is "God of God, Light of Light, very God of very God; begotten of the Father, not made; of one substance with the Father".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 18:6
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 18:7
verses.text: So, indeed, following the guidance of the Scriptures, our fathers declared, holding, moreover, that impious doctrines should be included in the record of their decrees, in order that the unbelief of Arius should discover itself, and not, as it were, mask itself with dye or face-paint.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 18:8
verses.text: For they give a false colour to their thoughts who dare not unfold them openly.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 18:9
verses.text: After the manner of the censor's rolls, then, the Arian heresy is not discovered by name, but marked out by the condemnation pronounced, in order that he who is curious and eager to hear it should be preserved from falling by knowing that it is condemned already, before he hears, it set forth to the end that he should believe.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 18:10
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 18:11
verses.text: "Those," runs the decree, "who say that there was a time when the Son of God was not, and that before He was born He was not, and who say that he was made out of nothing, or is of another substance or οὐσια, or that He is capable of changing, or that with Him is any shadow of turning,—them the Catholic and Apostolic Church declares accursed".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 18:12
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 18:13
verses.text: Your sacred Majesty has agreed that they who utter such doctrines are rightly condemned.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 18:14
verses.text: It was of no determination by man, of no human counsel, that three hundred and eighteen bishops met, as I showed above more at length, in Council, but that in their number the Lord Jesus might prove, by the sign of His Name and Passion, that He was in the midst, where His own were gathered together.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 18:15
verses.text: In the number of three hundred was the sign of His Cross, in that  of eighteen was the sign of the Name Jesus.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 18:16
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 18:17
verses.text: This also was the teaching of the First Confession in the Council of Ariminum, and of the Second Correction, after that Council.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 18:18
verses.text: Of the Confession, the letter sent to the Emperor Constantine beareth witness, and the Council that followed declares the Correction.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:1
verses.text: Chapter XIX.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:2
verses.text: Arius is charged with the first of the above-mentioned errors, and refuted by the testimony of St.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:3
verses.text: John.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:4
verses.text: The miserable death of the Heresiarch is described, and the rest of his blasphemous errors are one by one examined and disproved.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:5
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:6
verses.text: Arius, then, says: "There was a time when the Son of God existed not," but Scripture saith: "He was," not that "He was not".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:7
verses.text: Furthermore, St.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:8
verses.text: John has written: "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:9
verses.text: The same was in the beginning with God".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:10
verses.text: Observe how often the verb "was" appears, whereas "was not" is nowhere found.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:11
verses.text: Whom, then, are we to believe?—St.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:12
verses.text: John, who lay on Christ's bosom, or Arius, wallowing amid the outgush of his very bowels?—so wallowing that we might understand how Arius in his teaching showed himself like unto Judas, being visited with like punishment.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:13
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:14
verses.text: For Arius' bowels also gushed out—decency forbids to say where—and so he burst asunder in the midst, falling headlong, and besmirching those foul lips wherewith he had denied Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:15
verses.text: He was rent, even as the Apostle Peter said of Judas, because he "bought a field with the price of evil-doing, and falling headlong he burst asunder in the midst, and all his bowels gushed out".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:16
verses.text: It was no chance manner of death, seeing that like wickedness was visited with like punishment, to the end that those who denied and betrayed the same Lord might likewise undergo the same torment.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:17
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:18
verses.text: Let us pass on to further points.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:19
verses.text: Arius says: "Before He was born, the Son of God was not," but the Scripture saith that all things are maintained in existence by the Son's office.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:20
verses.text: How, then, could He, Who existed not, bestow existence upon others? Again, when the blasphemer uses the words "when" and "before," he certainly uses words which are marks of time.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:21
verses.text: How, then, do the Arians deny that time was ere the Son was, and yet will have things created in time to exist before the Son, seeing that the very words, "when," "before," and "did not exist once," announce the idea of time?  126.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:22
verses.text: Arius says that the Son of God came into being out of nought.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:23
verses.text: How, then, is He Son of God—how was He begotten from the womb of the Father—how do we read of Him as the Word spoken of the heart's abundance, save to the end that we should believe that He came forth, as it is written, from the Father's inmost, unapproachable sanctuary? Now a son is so called either by means of adoption or by nature, as we are called sons by means of adoption.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:24
verses.text: Christ is the Son of God by virtue of His real and abiding nature.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:25
verses.text: How, then, can He, Who out of nothing fashioned all things, be Himself created out of nothing?  127.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:26
verses.text: He who knows not whence the Son is hath not the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:27
verses.text: The Jews therefore had not the Son, for they knew not whence He was.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:28
verses.text: Wherefore the Lord said to them: "Ye know not whence I came;" and again: "Ye neither have found out Who I am, nor know My Father," for he who denies that the Son is of the Father knows not the Father, of Whom the Son is; and again, he knows not the Son, because he knows not the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:29
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:30
verses.text: Arius says: "[The Son is] of another Substance".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:31
verses.text: But what other substance is exalted to equality with the Son of God, so that simply in virtue thereof He is Son of God? Or what right have the Arians for censuring us because we speak, in Greek, of the οὐσία, or in Latin, of the Substantia of God, when they themselves, in saying that the Son of God is of another "Substance," assert a divine Substantia.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:32
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:33
verses.text: Howbeit, should they desire to dispute the use of the words "divine Substance" or "divine Nature," they shall easily be refuted, for Holy Writ oft-times hath spoken of οὐσία in Greek, or Substantia  in Latin, and St.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:34
verses.text: Peter, as we read, would have us become partakers in the divine Nature.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:35
verses.text: But if they will have it that the Son is of another "Substance," they with their own lips confute themselves, in that they both acknowledge the term "Substance," whereof they are so afraid, and rank the Son on a level with the creatures above which they feign to exalt Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:36
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:37
verses.text: Arius calls the Son of God a creature, but "not as the rest of the creatures".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:38
verses.text: Yet what created being is not different from another? Man is not as angel, earth is not as heaven, the sun is not as water, nor light as darkness.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:39
verses.text: Arius' preference, therefore, is empty—he hath but disguised with a sorry dye his deceitful blasphemies, in order to take the foolish.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:40
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:41
verses.text: Arius declares that the Son of God may change and swerve.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 19:42
verses.text: How, then, is He God if He is changeable, seeing that He Himself hath said: "I am, I am, and I change not"?.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 20

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 20:1
verses.text: Chapter XX.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 20:2
verses.text: St.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 20:3
verses.text: Ambrose declares his desire that some angel would fly to him to purify him, as once the Seraph did to Isaiah—nay more, that Christ Himself would come to him, to the Emperor, and to his readers, and finally prays that Gratian and the rest of the faithful may be exalted by the power and spell of the Lord's Cup, which he describes in mystic language.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 20:4
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 20:5
verses.text: Howbeit, now must I needs confess the Prophet Isaiah's confession, which he makes before declaring the word of the Lord: "Woe is me, my heart is smitten, for I, a man of unclean lips, and living in the midst of a people of unclean lips, have seen the Lord of Sabaoth".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 20:6
verses.text: Now if Isaiah said "Woe is me," who looked upon the Lord of Sabaoth, what shall I say of myself, who, being "a man of unclean lips," am constrained to treat of the divine generation? How shall I break forth into speech of things whereof I am afraid, when David prays that a watch may be set over his mouth in the matter of things whereof he has knowledge? O that to me also one of the Seraphim would bring the burning coal from the celestial altar, taking it in the tongs of the two testaments, and with the fire thereof purge my unclean lips!  133.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 20:7
verses.text: But forasmuch as then the Seraph came down in a vision to the Prophet, whilst Thou, O Lord, in revelation of the mystery hast come to us in the flesh, do Thou, not by any deputy, nor by any messenger, but Thou Thyself cleanse my conscience from my secret sins, that I too, erstwhile unclean, but now by Thy mercy made clean through faith, may sing in the words of David: "I will make music to Thee upon a harp, O God of Israel, my lips shall rejoice, in all my song to Thee, and so, too, shall my soul, whom Thou hast redeemed".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 20:8
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 20:9
verses.text: And so, O Lord, leaving them that slander and hate Thee, come unto us, sanctify the ears of our sovereign ruler, Gratian, and all besides into whose hands this little book shall come—and purge my ears, that no stains of the infidelity they have heard remain anywhere.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 20:10
verses.text: Cleanse thoroughly, then, our ears, not with water of well, river, or rippling and purling brook, but with words cleansing like water, clearer than any water, and purer than any snow—even the words Thou hast spoken—"Though your sins be as scarlet, I will make them white as snow".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 20:11
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 20:12
verses.text: Moreover, there is a Cup, wherewith Thou dost use to purify the hidden chambers of the soul, a Cup not of the old order, nor filled from a common Vine,—a new Cup, brought down from heaven to earth, filled with wine pressed from the wondrous cluster, which hung in fleshly form upon the tree of the Cross, even as the grape hangs upon the Vine.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 20:13
verses.text: From this Cluster, then, is the Wine that maketh glad the heart of man, uplifts the sorrowful, is fragrant with, pours into us, the ecstasy of faith, true devotion, and purity.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 20:14
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 20:15
verses.text: With this Wine, therefore, O Lord my God, cleanse the spiritual ears of our sovereign Emperor, to the end that, just as men, being uplifted with common wine, love rest and quietness, cast out the fear of death, have no feeling of injuries, seek not that which belongs to others, and forget  their own; and so he, too, intoxicated with thy wine, may love peace, and, confident in the exultation of faith, may never know the death of unbelief, and may display loving patience, have no part in other men's profanities, and hold the faith of more account even than kindred and children, as it is written: "Leave all that thou hast, and come, follow Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 20:16
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 20:17
verses.text: With this Wine, also, Lord Jesus, purify our senses, that we may adore Thee, and worship Thee, the Creator of things visible and invisible.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book I 20:18
verses.text: Truly, Thou canst not fail of being Thyself invisible and good, Who hast given invisibility and goodness to the works of Thy Hands.
